title: Virginia and New Jersey report first vaping-related fatalities, bringing the US death toll up to 17
text:
Virginia and New Jersey have each reported their first deaths related to vaping, bringing the US total count up to 17.

The death in Virginia, an adult who lived in the southwest region, occurred on September 26 at a hospital in Greensboro, North Carolina.

The New Jersey death, an adult female who lived in the northern part of the state, occurred in August.

No details about either victims' names or ages are being released to protect the privacy of their respective families.

The Virginia resident died on September 26 at a hospital in Greensboro, North Carolina and the death of the New Jersey resident, an adult female, occurred in August (file image)

On Thursday, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) announced that 12 deaths had been confirmed in California, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri and Oregon.

Since then, three deaths have also been reported by state departments in Nebraska, North Carolina and Oregon.

At least 805 have fallen ill nationwide from 46 states and one territory, the majority of patients said they had vaped THC, the main psychoactive ingredient in marijuana.

As of Tuesday, 31 lung injury cases, including the death, have been reported in Virginia.

In New Jersey, 14 confirmed and probable cases have been reported, according to the state's Department of Health Acting Commissioner Judith Persichill.

Over the summer, health officials in several states began noticing reports of people with severe lung diseases. The only common factor in the mounting cases was that all the patients had recently vaped.

The number of reported vaping-related illnesses soared as a national investigation got underway.

Since the illnesses began appearing over the summer, several states have taken measures to attempt to prevent more cases.

Temporary bans on flavored vaping products have gone into effect in New York, Michigan and Rhode Island, and Washington is set to be the fourth state to enact a similar rule.

Massachusetts has gone the farthest, issuing a four-month ban on all vaping products - flavored or not.

The Virginia Department of Health said that although the cause of the outbreak has not been pinpointed, it implored residents to not vape.

'Regardless of the ongoing investigation, people who use e-cigarette products should not buy these products off the street and should not modify e-cigarette products or add any substances that are not intended by the manufacturer,' a statement read.
description: The Virginia resident died on September 26 at a hospital in Greensboro, North Carolina and the death of the New Jersey resident, an adult female, occurred in August, state officials said.
